Notes on Crashcourse Philosophy Video 5: Cartesian Skepticism-Neo, Meet Rene

Summarizes plot of Matrix


Humans live in vats where wires connected to their brains make them think they are living normal lives. Neo and some friends choose to fight rather than return to the comfortable lie of their former lives.


Could we be living in a Matrix? Rene Descartes thought so. He was famously skeptical about how he knew what he knew. (This has to do with epistemology, the study of knowledge.)


Skeptics wonder if it’s possible to know anything for certain. Descartes started Cartesian Skepticism. 


Descartes decided to disbelieve everything to prevent false beliefs. Analogy: upend a basket of apples (beliefs) and only put non-rotten (right) beliefs back in the basket


Started with empirical beliefs, beliefs that come from the 5 senses. But our senses aren’t fully reliable—sometimes we think we are awake when we are dreaming, and sometimes we think we see a friend up ahead but they are actually a different person. 


Local doubts: doubts about a particular sense experience or other occurrence at a particular point in time. The idea is that when the situation changes you can check whether the experience was reliable or not. E.g. wake up from your dream you thought was real


But what if everything is deceptive?  (GLOBAL DOUBT)


Bertrand Russell: created 5-minute hypothesis 


What if universe was created 5 minutes ago? (God makes things look like they are old and gives ppl false memories.) No way to prove this didn’t happen. Does this matter though? Rene thought so.


Descartes thought that an evil genius could be deceiving us. Everything we believe and experience could be an evil genius deceiving us.


Descartes was sure that he was doubting. If he’s sure he’s doubting, he is sure that he is a thinking thing. 


Declared, COGITO ERGO SUM. I think, therefore I am. I am definitely a mind with thoughts. Descartes had a clear and distinct idea that God existed. Determined God wouldn’t let him have clear and distinct ideas of a false reality with no way of detecting his error. So he was able to fill up his whole apple basket.


Philosophers debate whether Descartes had proper justification to proceed past Cogito Ergo Sum. 


Questions: How is the plot of the Matrix similar to Descartes’ epistemological fears? Define local doubts and global doubts. What type of belief did Descartes start with, and why weren’t these beliefs reliable? What is Bertrand Russel’s 5-minute hypothesis, and how does it relate to Descartes’ fears about reality? What does cogito ergo sum mean? What did it mean Descartes could be sure of? How did Descartes fill up his apple basket again?

I was never happy with Des Carte's "I think, therefore I am" claim. It seemed very presumptious to me, so I refined it.
How can we know for certain that we are truly thinking? How can we declare that we are, on such tenuous circumstantial evidence? We CAN doubt our existence. Even if it appears we are having such a thought, we cannot be certain of it.
So my re-working of Des Carte's axiom is:
I THINK I think, therefore I THINK I am.
Much better. No more arrogant assumptions about what's going on. We don't truly know we are thinking, we only appear to do so, and we don't truly KNOW that we are, we can only be certain that we THINK we are.
This is a much more accurate and supportable statement, leading to much the same place, but without any of the arrogant assumptions along the way, so please tell everyone that Des Carte may have overstepped the mark, and explain the new, sounder reasoning to humanity, so they don't continue to arrogantly assume that they exist without actually having any hard evidence for it.

It's pretty common to see other people wondering, "Is anything I'm seeing real? Is all of it a stimulation?" and for that I too once wondered it a lot as a child. However, those thoughts also made me think about something similar.
Sounds weird at first, but we know that most humans feel self conscious about being seen naked. In the shower (yes, shower thoughts), I kept thinking, "Despite the bathroom being closed in every way possible so there's no way for anyone to see me showering, what if there is someone still watching me but I'm just unaware of it?". That thought eventually turned into, "What if everything I'm seeing right now isn't real - perhaps an illusion or a stimulation -, but the actions I'm doing [In this case, showering] are still occurring in the 'real' world and that I'm just completely unaware of it?".
And as a kid I kept thinking of this strange thought: What if what I'm seeing right now seems to be a normal life, but in reality I'm just a naked person in a cage, and every action I'm doing right now is happening in that cage. People walk by and think I'm crazy or have a problem. Perhaps it was just the paranoia or embarrassing myself without knowing, but it's quite crazy looking back and thinking, "Wow, I thought of THAT!"

Someone told you, “I think therefore I am.” Is that really true? It is only because you exist that you can generate a thought, isn’t it? Your thought process has become so compulsive, and your focus has shifted from your existence to your thought to such an extent, that now you are beginning to believe that you exist because you think. Even without your silly thoughts, existence is. What can you think, really? Just the nonsense that you have gathered and recycled. Can you think something other than what has been fed into your head? All you are doing is recycling old data. This recycling has become so important that people even dare to say “I think, therefore I am.” And that has become the world’s way of life.

Because you are, you can think. If you choose, you can fully be and still not think. The most beautiful moments in your life – moments of bliss, moments of joy, moments of ecstasy, moments of utter peace – were moments when you were not thinking about anything. You were just living.

Do you want to be a living being or a thinking being? Right now, ninety percent of the time you are only thinking about life, not living life. Have you come here to experience life or to think about life? Everybody can think up their own nonsense whichever way they want; it need not have anything to do with reality. Your psychological process is a very small happening compared to the life process, but right now it has become far more important. We need to shift the significance to the life process once again.

Aristotle is known as the father of modern logic; his logic was immaculate. He was intellectually brilliant, no question about that, but he tried to stretch logic to all aspects of life, and in many ways he was crippled.

There is a story, I do not know if it is a fact, but it smells true. One day, Aristotle was walking on the beach. A glorious sunset was happening, but he had no time for such petty daily events. He was thinking seriously about some great problem of existence, because for Aristotle, existence is a problem, and he believes he is going to solve it. Thinking seriously, he was walking up and down the beach. There was another man on the beach who was doing something very intensely – so intensely that even Aristotle could not ignore him.

You know, people who think too much about their own nonsense end up ignoring life around them. They are the people who don’t smile at anybody or even look at anybody in the world. They have no eyes to look at a flower, a sunset, a child or a smiling face – or if it is an unsmiling face, they have no inclination to make it smile; they have no such small duties or small cares in the world! They ignore all the life around them because they are all busy, solving the problems of existence.

But Aristotle could not ignore this man, and he closely observed what he was doing: this man was going to the ocean, coming back, going to the ocean, coming back, all with great intensity. So Aristotle stopped and asked, “Hey, what are you up to?”

The man said, “Don’t disturb me, I am doing something very important,” and went on and on.

Aristotle became even more curious and asked, “What are you doing?”

The man said, “Don’t disturb me, something very important.”

Aristotle said, “What is this important thing?”

The man showed a little hole he had dug in the sand, and he said, “I am emptying the ocean into this hole.” He had a tablespoon in his hand.

Aristotle looked at this and laughed. Now, Aristotle is the kind who can spend a year without a single moment of laughter, because he is intellect. It takes a heart to laugh. Intellect cannot laugh; it can only dissect.

But even Aristotle laughed at this and said, “This is ridiculous! You must be insane. Do you know how vast this ocean is? How can you ever empty this ocean into this little hole? And that too, with a tablespoon? At least if you have a bucket, there’s some chance. Please give this up; this is madness, I am telling you.”

The man looked at Aristotle, threw the spoon down and said, “My job is already done.”

Aristotle said, “What do you mean? Forget about the ocean being empty; even the hole is not full. How can you say your job is done?”

The other man was Heraclitus. Heraclitus stood up and said, “I am trying to empty the ocean into this hole with a tablespoon. You are telling me it’s ridiculous, it’s madness, so I should give it up. What are you trying to do? Do you know how vast this existence is? It can contain a billion oceans like this and more, and you are trying to empty it into the small hole of your head – and with what? With tablespoons called thoughts. Please give it up. It’s utterly ridiculous.”

If you want to know the experiential dimensions of life, you will never know it with petty thought. It does not matter how well you can think, human thought is still petty. Even if you have Einstein’s brain working within you, it is still petty because thought cannot be bigger than life. Thought can only be logical, functioning between two polarities. If you want to know life in its immensity, you need something more than your thoughts, something more than your logic, something more than your intellect.

This is the choice you have: either you learn to live with creation, or you create your own nonsensical creation in your head. Which option do you want to exercise? Right now, most people are living in thoughts, something in a psychological space, not in an existential space. And so they are insecure, because it can collapse any moment.

The planet is spinning on time. Not a small event. All galaxies are going perfectly well, the whole cosmos is doing great. But you have one nasty little thought crawling through your head, and it is a bad day.

You have the freedom to think whatever you want. Why don’t you just think pleasant thoughts? The problem is just this: you have a computer for which you have not bothered to find the keypad. If you had the keypad, you might type the right words, isn’t it? You don’t have the keypad, and you are punching your computer like a cave man, so all the wrong words keep coming up. Try this with your computer; the result will look like an obscenity.

You have lost your perspective of life because you think you are much more than you are. In cosmic space, if you look at yourself in perspective, you are less than a speck of dust, but you think your thought – which is less than a speck in you – should determine the nature of existence. What I think and what you think is not of any importance. What is important is the grandeur of existence — the only reality.

You have heard of the word “Buddha.” One who has risen above his intellect, or one who has risen above the discriminatory and logical dimension of his life, is a Buddha. Human beings have invented millions of ways to suffer. For all this the manufacturing unit is just in your mind. When you have risen above your mind, this is the end of suffering. When there is no fear of suffering, there is absolute freedom. Only when this happens, a man is free to experience life beyond his limitations. So being a Buddha means that you have become a witness to your own intellect. The essence of yoga and meditation is just this: once you have a clear space between you and your mind, you experience a completely different dimension of existence.

"Cartesian skepticism" is a misnomer. Descartes was not a skeptic. He was an extreme optimist about knowledge. He thought that we can obtain knowledge from innate ideas of substances through a priori reflection. He used skeptical scenarios as a method to lead the meditator away from the distractions of the senses (which are misleading in his view - as the video points out) to the infallible innate ideas. The best example for Descartes is the appearance of retrograde motion. When we use our senses, we think that planets sometimes stop in their paths, turn around, go backwards for a bit, then go forward again. In fact, if we follow our senses it looks like the sun goes around the earth not the other way around. When we reason geometrically, using innate ideas of material substance, we realize that the appearance of retrograde motion of the planets, and of the sun's path across the daytime sky, are a projective illusions. Descartes emphatically did not reach these conclusions by reasoning from the cogito. The cogito only serves as an example of a proposition that he cannot doubt because he clearly and distinctly perceives it to be true. He then goes on to use the standard of clarity and distinctness to identify other propositions about infinite substance (God) and finite substances (body and mind) that he similarly cannot doubt. He reasons from the nature of these substances to the conclusions described in the video, not directly from the cogito. I'm not saying all of this works. It's subject to well known objections. Getting the gist of his philosophical program across in 10 minutes for a popular audience is pretty challenging. I'm not hating, but I do think at least the video could have been careful about emphasizing methodological skepticism vs actual skepticism (Sextus Empiricus) and the "reasoning from the cogito" is a kind of sloppy way to put it.

There's no need to talk about The Matrix in purely philosophical terms. Top physicists have been telling us since 1925, when quantum mechanics was discovered, that we do indeed live in a virtual reality. Just like in a video game, players only see what they need to see when they need to see it. The rest is kept track of by a computer (or source outside the game/universe). In 2005, astrophysicist Richard Conn Henry wrote a now-famous essay in the leading science journal Nature entitled "The mental Universe," in which he chastised the physics community for not making this greatest of all discoveries more widely known. The Matrix is based on quantum mechanics rather than Descartes, although the two naturally go hand in hand.

If I think I see my friend, but then realize it's not him at all, I realize that through sense experience--by seeing the stranger more closely and clearly. I also measure the appearance of the person closely and clearly to my remembered sense perceptions of my friend. Now we can have false memories, but that does not mean our senses are entirely false. It is fine to doubt sense experience in particular instances, but not accross the board.

Sorry to correct you, but 'cogito ergo sum' is one of the most misquoted quotes in philosophy. It is not taken from the 'Meditations' (1641). It first appeared, in french ('Je pence donc je suis') in the the 'Discourse on the Method' (1637) and later appeared, in latin, in 'Principles of Philosophy' (1644). The closest Descartes gets to saying 'I think therefore I am' in the 'Meditations' is when he declares, 'I am. I exist.'

Descartes never wrote "Cogito ergo sum".
His famous novel "Discours de la méthode" was written in French, not Latin, and the quote was "je pense donc je suis" ("I think therefore I am").
This would be like quoting the Declaration of Independence and saying "omnes homines pares creantur" instead of "all men are created equal".
Saying it in Latin doesn't make it smarter or truer.

The example with the food; we are sick, so the food tastes different due to the body requiring a different formation than our regular meals, same when you are full and don't like the taste of food, the sense is telling you do not eat any more, or when we are hungry the senses are saying eat more.  The tap feels hotter after you come in from the cold is because the body adjusted to the colder temperature so the feeling of the water is warm since the body is in a different state of how well it can absorb heat and how much it should.  All these examples and effects are not the senses failing us but doing what they should be doing for the best actions by the person themselves, it is simply the way we interpret the senses that can lead to problems... I entirely trust my senses 100%, if a reaction occurs that negatively affects me I don't blame my senses at all but my ability to understand the reason for that sense; with this understanding I have been able to trust my senses more and more.

Descartes' professed Christian faith and his scepticism are totally incompatible. The nature, attributes and revelation of God are in fact the only basis for having justified beliefs, that is, knowledge. With just "Cogito ergo sum" (please, read that as Co-gee-to) the best one can do is to be a solipsist. Also, the positing of the evil genius while believing in the Christian God is completely contradictory, as the existence of entity that's trapped us into a virtual reality is impossible in the universe created by Yahweh. We know the world is real the way we perceive it because of God's general, internal and special revelation. Deny that, and you're led to absurdity.

To be fair to Renee, even if he hadn't leapt to the conclusion that god exists based on him just really really wanting it badly, he would have had to do so anyway because the 1600s were not a safe space for radical thinkers.  Safer than the middle ages, to be sure, but it's worth remembering that Descartes lived at the same time as the Thirty Years' War, a largely religious conflict so bloody and brutal that it nearly depopulated central Europe.  Making enemies of both Protestants and Catholics by not rushing to a god-affirming conclusion could well have ended in tragedy for him.

Descartes the Mac-Daddy of all skeptics? I would have considered the original greeks who the term was named after would be the mac-daddies. We have Pyrrhonic and Academic varieties with the respective shining states of Sextus Empiricus and Carneades. But I could understand if you didn't want to choose either, and ended up with the philosopher that many say most embodies the skeptical mindset which was Socrates.

Descartes by comparison, on skepticism, was a dumbed down version of these guys. Sure his thought experiments allowed skepticism to be more-easily understood by the religious zealots, but philosophically his impact was minimal while the others are still debated to this day. I don't want to take away from Descartes other Renaissance contributions, but his contributions to skepticism were child's play compared to his predecessors.

why is it that, from my experience, the Internet is full of atheists demeaning people of faith. Religion/faith is the product of accumulated knowledge of experiences by various individuals who have similar experiences which cannot be measured or tested. They trust that their experience is real just like everyone trusts that this reality is real and/or also trust that others are telling the truth. There is no way to prove or disprove it, that's why it's faith. Yes, not every faith can be right, but simply because one is not does not mean all are not. There have been miracles, things that cannot be logically explained, but people go into denial rather than accept the possibility of its validity, that doesn't mean you have to believe everything, but at least show respect. (this is a complicated and hard subject because as a person of faith with morality, since morality cannot be objectively proven, I can argue against hate, but can't really objectively since it may be someone else's belief, therefore, apart from I think therefore I am, every argument must be founded on shared beliefs with the person I'm arguing with.)

also, to be a real atheist, you cannot logically have morality. An atheist who believes in nothing but what can be proven and measured within this reality they have assumed to be true, cannot then logically believe that there is such a thing as right and wrong. Therefore, the most logical thing to do is live life focused only on self gain, pleasure, in an opportunistic, selfish, manner only obeying moral codes to gain something such as trust etc. That means that if you can get away with murder to gain something, you do it because it is the most rational thing to do since there is not right and wrong. Those who say morality comes from yourself or just being a good person are using circular logic or using baseless, arbitrary morals which limit self gain and are therefore illogical. If there is no reward for good actions when you die and you cease to exist, then why would you not live selfishly?

every atheist that claims to have morals but no faith other than in the existence of this material reality, is both not a real atheist (under my definition) and also illogical

religion provides a source of morality, because if you believe your faith to be true, then the morality is objective, not arbitrary

also, I don't understand how there are people doubting their own existence, I get the line of thinking where you doubt the origin of your thoughts, but to doubt your own existence is illogical. also, if you exist but cannot prove your body does, doesn't that mean you are not your body and therefore have a soul? and how do you know you'll cease to exist after death? have you always existed or were you created? by who or what? etc.

What follows is more unimportant ponderings from me.

Descartes' cogito does not necessarily prove anything about "me" or "I." I think, therefore I am (a thinking thing). So how does this thinking thing know that it's not a head in a vat of KY Jelly? It doesn't. Furthermore, as it has been pointed out time and again, the two instances of "I" aren't necessarily the same referent. Perhaps there are two I's. To be a thinking thing, to exist as a thinking and doubting thing does not preclude being fooled about anything other than the experience of thought and doubt. I think therefore I am a thinking thing is the most fair parsing, and it gives you nothing. It certainly doesn't give you the ontological argument and it doesn't show that you are not being fooled. It merely proves that I exist, even if I am a solipsistic individual that will forever talk to only myself. It is maddening. It is far easier to avoid all of the doubts that we can summon with a few philosophical razors, rather than think our way out of them via Descartes' method. It is probably even easier to avoid them altogether and study medicine or business or history or science or something. I jest.

Cheers.

Alright, so I disagree with the idea that "I think, therefore I am" is a foundational belief.

If we take a look at a computer program, for example, we wouldn't say that the program thinks. Rather the program is simply does as it's programed. So if it were programmed to say the words "I think, therefore I am" we would say that the program isn't actually thinking, it's just being told to say that. Upon further investigation we can also say that the program doesn't really exist, it only exist in the context of it's surroundings. Take away the cloud, computer, whatever it operates in and there's nothing left. It doesn't really exist, it's just an idea.

What if we're no different? What if our perception of "ourselves thinking" is not "ourselves" thinking, but rather something else telling us to say that? What if we're simply programs? And if so, what if we take away the context that we exist in (what we perceive as reality)? What if our existence is simply an idea (of who knows what) and there's nothing that I can call "me"?

Thoughts?

Isn't there a problem with Descartes' foundational belief, though? He has to exist because of his thoughts, as thoughts cannot exist without a thinker. We know this because of cause and effect; everything must originate from somewhere. The problem with this, though, is that it is founded on the premise "Everything originates from somewhere." Is there any proof for this premise?

Sure, we have evidence that almost everything around us comes from somewhere, but that's irrelevant. That only proves that things can have a source, not that they must have a source. There's no way to prove all things ever have an origin. It is impossible to know that you know of all things because there's no way to verify it. That's akin to taking attendance by asking the people who aren't there to raise their hands, then going on assuming everybody is there.

Anyways, this is a bit unformed, but my main idea is that the idea that thoughts require a thinker is based solely on precedent. It's absence of evidence, not evidence of absence.

the fascinating thing about 'I think therefore I am' is, that Descartes' mind is probably the thing he valued about himself above all others, and that is the thing he chose to prove his own existence. I think therefore I am. What I find fascinating about this is that our biases lead our conclusions. And certainly that is how we define ourselves, by holding certain qualities about others, perhaps even to the exclusion of others; for example, I am shy, therefore I can't be brave. So basically, what 'I think therefore I am' basically comes down to is a solution to an identity crisis, rather than an evaluation of the world. Certainly, how we perceive ourselves colours how we see the world; outside of our own brains, what can be the world...?

Which brings us back around to Descartes' conclusion: I think therefore I am -- we are -- the world is. If anything can be defined, and therefore understood, it must be in our own brains, even as each of us draw our own unique conclusions and definitions and associations. While the universe continues living and dying, while we manufacture, while nature reposes, there we are, watching. Philosophers may ask, what is the meaning of life? But it's only in our own minds it needs defining, due to our own needs and flaws.

In other words, philosophy is psychology.

But what if? What if we are all just parts of one massive sentience? All of us are just manifestations of it's thoughts? What if they aren't even thoughts, but emotions? A being that feels trillions of emotions all at once and needs us to exhibit all of it or else it dies? It emotes therefore we are? And it keeps growing and growing with the ages, so needs more and more beings for it' emotions? What happens to it if some external force destroys us? Would it explode? Or just make more? I think therefore I am, something must exist of us for us to think, yes. But what if it's not about that? I dunno I'm just carrying on

What happens if we think of the world that we are living in as actually being an imaginative script inside of an authors head who is just thinking out scenarios? If I am just a character in someone else's thoughts and I am thinking but, only because they are thinking I am thinking. Am I still a reality because the "author" is thinking as me? Or am I considered just a thought, another happy illusion? Then because I have the power to imagine, or perceive that I do, do my imagined characters become real, or remain illusions? After all Harry Potter a "fictional" character has had more influence over real peoples lives than some, if not most, biographies of "real" people. So which is more real? The character who influenced many but was imagined or the person who influenced few but existed?..Assuming that they aren't both just some figment of some super beings imagination at multiple levels.... Because if it is someone else thinking, this would all be a "local doubt" for them and a "global doubt" for all of the characters imagined. So in the end I guess I am asking if whether or not we can be sure that it is we who are thinking? Not just another being thinking for us and as us, like an author does..or does that temporary conscience create a new reality? And therefore are authors imagined characters now also real?...I'm down a rabbit hole here.

Here's the problem with the cogito of Descartes: it assumes "I think." Descartes makes this intellectual leap with no real reason to do so (other than he feels it must be the case). If you are being truly deceived by a demon that can control your memories, then it can control your present thoughts to, and you also have no reason to believe you are not merely a figment of the imagination. Not only is Descartes argument to belief circular (as I'm sure the later episode will point out), but his foundational belief is as well.

I once studied The Matrix through a philosophy and religious lens for a whole year and yet I still learned something new in this video - which I didn't think was possible at this point.
Anyway, it was that Descartes is not pronounced Dez-car-tez. Words are hard.

While Descartes "I think therefore I am" is well justified, the fact that he ended up believing that all of his prior beliefs were true is very worrisome. Rarely do we do anything perfectly, and mistakes are nearly always made, so it seems nearly impossible that his line of reasoning worked. Even ignoring this, the fact that he continues his belief in God, and uses that as a way to explain some of his other beliefs indicates to me that he didn't really succeed in questioning all he "knew". I'm not going to argue whether God is real or not, that feels like it's for another time, but what I will say is that, if he had truly questioned all of his preconceived notions and properly questioned and justified belief in God, I don't think we'd see a lot of the controversy we see about whether God is real. This goes to discredit a lot of what he concluded, I think. Sure, some might say that we have to take certain liberties to make any sort of conclusion or analysis, but if that's the best defense of Descartes reasoning, in the respect of questioning everything and assuming nothing, he has failed.
